questions.question:
Question 1: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma are least likely to present with  
.
questions.explanation:
Jaundice is an uncommon sign of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignancy of the liver. It is commonly 
seen in men aged 50-60 years who present with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, weight 
loss, and a palpable mass. Non-specific symptoms of the advanced malignant disease are anorexia, nausea, lethargy. The 
gross appearance shows unifocal or multifocal or diffusely infiltrative lesions that are paler than 
the surrounding tissue.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Oral contraceptive use is not an independent risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a risk 
factor for developing hepatic adenoma. 721 
Sold by @itachibot Although hepatocellular adenoma can undergo malignant transformation, the true risk is low 
(10%). Major risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma: • Infection: • Hepatitis B • Hepatitis C • Toxins/drugs: • Alcoholic cirrhosis • Aflatoxins • Anabolic steroids • Genetic: • Hemochromatosis • 1-Antitrypsin deficiency • Immunological: • Autoimmune chronic active hepatitis • Primary biliary cirrhosis • Others: • Obesity • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis • Cirrhosis (other causes and idiopathic).

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following can be seen with HCC?
questions.explanation:
Paraneoplastic syndrome due to hepatocellular carcinoma can manifest as: • Hypercalcemia • Hypoglycemia • Erythrocytosis Hypercalcemia in patients with HCC is associated with increased renal reabsorption of 
calcium and increased bone resorption by parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) 
generated by HCC. Less than 1% of cases of HCC manifest with a paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 57-year-old man presented with persistent upper abdominal pain and weight loss. 
Ultrasound revealed a lesion in the right lobe of the liver and contrast-enhanced CT was 
suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following tumor markers can be 
elevated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Alpha-2-macroglobulin is not a tumor marker of HCC. 722 
Sold by @itachibot Tumor markers of HCC are: • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) • Normal (<20 ng/mL), • Elevated (21–400 ng/mL), and • Diagnostic for HCC (>400 ng/mL). • Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonist - II (PIVKA-II) also called 
des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP) • Glypican 3. • Neurotensin (in fibrolamellar type)

questions.question:
Question 5: A 43-year-old man presented to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, ascites, and 
weight loss for 6 months. Investigations revealed a thrombus in the portal vein along with 
invasion from nearby tumor growth. Which of the following conditions can cause this?
questions.explanation:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has a secondary Budd-Chiari syndrome due to portal 
vein obstruction by a neighboring invasive lesion. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has the 
highest tendency to invade the portal vein. Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the 
obstruction of hepatic venous outflow.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is not true regarding the fibrolamellar variant of HCC?

options.b: Recurrences are seen despite better prognosis
options.c: Occur under the age of 35 years
options.d: Not commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B infection

questions.explanation:
Fibrolamellar variant of HCC is not commonly associated with liver cirrhosis. Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive variant (<5%) of HCC. They occur under the age of 35 
years, without any gender predilection or identifiable predisposing conditions. It usually presents as a single large, hard 'scirrhous' tumor. The tumor is well-demarcated, 
encapsulated, and may have a central fibrotic area. Histology shows large polygonal cells 
embedded in a fibrous stroma forming lamellar structures.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 25-year-old male patient is found to have a well-circumscribed mass in his liver and is 
suspected to have fibrolamellar HCC. Which of the following tumor markers will be elevated 
in his condition?
questions.explanation:
Neurotensin is the tumor marker of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Neurotensin is a mitogen which induces cell proliferation in fibrolamellar hepatocellular 
carcinoma. There is increased serum unsaturated vitamin B12 binding capacity seen in 
fibrolamellar HCC which can also aid in diagnosis.

questions.question:
Question 8: 716 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements is not true about alpha-fetoprotein?

options.a: AFP level does not return back to normal after hepatic resection
options.b: Levels of >400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings is suggestive of HCC
options.c: AFP level can be raised in benign conditions

questions.explanation:
723 
Sold by @itachibot Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level returns to normal after resection. Alpha-fetoprotein is a glycoprotein that is produced in early fetal life by the liver. It is also 
produced by a variety of tumors, such as: • Hepatocellular carcinoma • Hepatoblastoma • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal 
carcinoma). AFP is also elevated during the following conditions: • Pregnancy and in benign liver disease (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis) • Gastrointestinal tract tumors • Along with carcinoembryonic antigen in ataxia-telangiectasia Limitations of AFP include low sensitivity and specificity. It is not specific to HCC and can occur 
with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal metastases. Levels >400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings are suggestive of HCC. Alpha-fetoprotein 
(AFP) is not elevated in fibrolamellar HCC.

questions.question: Question 9: AFP is used as a tumor marker in which of the following cancers?
questions.explanation:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not a tumor marker used to detect cholangiocarcinoma or fibrolamellar 
HCC. It is produced by a variety of tumors such as: • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) • Hepatoblastoma • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal 
carcinoma).

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following are modalities of treatment in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
All of the given modalities can be used for the treatment of HCC. Treatment options for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): • Surgical • Resection (the mainstay of treatment) • Orthotopic liver transplantation • Ablative • Percutaneous ethanol injection (PEI) (less frequently used nowadays) • Thermal ablation (cryotherapy, radiofrequency ablation, microwave, Nd-YAG laser) 724 
Sold by @itachibot • Transarterial • Embolization • Chemoembolization • Radiotherapy • Combination of transarterial and ablative: external beam radiation • Systemic • Chemotherapy • Hormonal • Immunotherapy

questions.question:
Question 11: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with localized hepatocellular carcinoma. He falls into 
child-pugh class A and his future liver remnant is 22% of the total liver volume. Which of the 
following will decrease the tumor burden and improve his hepatic functional reserve?

options.b: Preoperative portal vein embolization followed by resection

questions.explanation:
The patient should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization to improve hepatic 
functional reserve, followed by resection which will decrease the tumor burden. Portal venous embolization on the side of the tumor will lead to compensatory hypertrophy of the 
unaffected liver lobe. This improves the volume and function of the future liver remnant (FLR). Localized hepatocellular carcinoma • Child-Pugh class A: Patients with child-pugh class A should undergo resection of the tumor. • Those with low FLR (<30%) should ideally be treated by preoperative portal vein embolization 
followed by resection. Preoperative embolization helps in improving the FLR volume function 
prior to resection. • Those with adequate FLR (>30-40%) can usually tolerate resection alone. • Child-Pugh class B/C or portal hypertension: Patients with early-stage HCC and child-Pugh class 
B/C or portal hypertension should be considered for transplantation. Advanced hepatocellular carcinoma Patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma are treated with palliative intent. Following are 
the management options: • Drug therapy - Sorafenib/ Sunitinib/ Regorafenib • Transarterial chemoembolisation (TACE) and transarterial radioembolisation (TARE) offer the 
best results in multifocal disease • Radiofrequency ablation, microwave ablation, high-frequency ultrasound therapy are alternative 
options • Patients with extreme deterioration of performance status and liver function should be offered 
supportive treatment only.

questions.question:
Question 12: 717 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following parameters is not considered in OKUDA staging?
questions.explanation:
725 
Sold by @itachibot OKUDA staging includes assessment of all the above factors except alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). The OKUDA staging system distinguishes patients with poor prognosis from those with more 
potential for long-term survival. The OKUDA staging system is an older system. OKUDA staging system for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): Stage I: 0 points Stage II: 1-2 points Stage III: 3-4 points Clinical paramet

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following scoring systems will you not use to assess oncological outcomes of 
patients with hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score is not used to assess the oncological outcome of 
patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. MELD is used to predict the severity of end-stage chronic 
liver disease. Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer staging system (BCLC) is the most commonly used scoring system 
for staging and management of HCC. The staging or management of HCC is done by the following: 1. Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer staging system (BCLC) • Tumor score (TNM) • Child-Pugh score • Performance score(Barcelona clinic score) 2. Cancer of the Liver Italian Program (CLIP) • Tumor size • Child-Pugh score • AFP • Portal vein thrombosis 3. OKUDA staging • Bilirubin • Ascites 726 
Sold by @itachibot • Tumor size • Albumin 4. Chinese University Prognostic Index (CUPI) Note: MELD can be used in prioritizing HCC patients in need of liver transplants.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is true regarding LI-RADS scoring?

options.a: LI-RADS 2 has an intermediate probability of malignancy
options.b: Treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma can be initiated in LI-RADS 5 without biopsy
options.c: LI-RADS 3 is an indication for immediate liver biopsy
options.d: LI-RADS 4 is definitive of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.explanation:
LI-RADS 5 indicates a definitive probability(~100%) of hepatocellular carcinoma. Therefore 
treatment can be initiated as early as possible without waiting for a biopsy. • Routine surveillance should be continued for LI-RADS 1, 2. Additional imaging may be required 
for LI-RADS 2 based on individual risk. • LI-RADS 3 should be evaluated by serial imaging every 3-6 months. • Evaluation with a biopsy should be done in LI-RADS 4. • Since LI-RADS 5 indicates a definitive probability of hepatocellular carcinoma, treatment can be 
initiated as early as possible without waiting for a biopsy. Liver Imaging Reporting and 
Data Systems (LI-RADS) cate 
gories Category 
Assessment LI-RADS 1 
Definitely benign LI-RADS 2 
Probably benign LI-RADS 3 
Intermediate probability of 
malignancy LI-RADS 4 
Probably HCC LI-RADS 5 
Definitely HCC

questions.question:
Question 15: A 70-year-old retiree was employed for two decades in a plastic industry, where he was 
exposed to vinyl chloride. He is at an increased risk of developing which of the following 
tumors?
questions.explanation:
Angiosarcoma of the liver is seen in workers who have been exposed to vinyl chloride for 
prolonged periods. Angiosarcoma is the most common malignant mesenchymal tumor of the liver. It is a rare and 
fatal tumor. They are associated with the following conditions: • Hemochromatosis • Neurofibromatosis type I • Exposure to vinyl chloride, thorium dioxide, and arsenic. 727 
Sold by @itachibot Patients usually present with vague symptoms of abdominal pain, weakness, fatigue, and weight 
loss. A hepatic bruit is occasionally heard, reflecting the vascular nature of the tumor. Central hypovascularity, vascular lakes, and peripheral contrast staining on arteriography are 
suggestive of an angiosarcoma. Biopsy shows the presence of dilated sinusoids lined by atypical 
endothelial cells.

questions.question:
Question 16: An infant is brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of poor feeding and 
abdominal distension. On evaluation, a mass is detected in the liver which is later diagnosed 
to be a hepatoblastoma. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: It is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis
options.b: Most cases occur before the age of 3 years
options.c: Treatment is surgical resection followed by chemotherapy
options.d: Prognosis is extremely poor for pulmonary metastasis

questions.explanation:
In hepatoblastoma, 85% of patients with pulmonary metastases can be successfully treated with 
resection of the hepatic tumor and chemotherapy or resection of the pulmonary metastases. Hepatoblastoma is the most common primary hepatic tumor of childhood. The median age at 
presentation is 18 months, and almost all cases occur before 3 years of age. It has been associated 
with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome. This tumor generally manifests as an asymptomatic mass. Mild anemia and thrombocytosis are 
commonly found at presentation. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in the majority of patients and can serve as a 
useful marker for therapeutic response. Treatment includes chemotherapy that can help downstage tumors such that they are amenable to 
resection. In patients without metastatic disease or the anaplastic variant, long-term survival rates 
of 60% to 70% can be expected with complete resection. Staging of pediatric liver tumors: Stage 
Feature Stage I 
No metastasesTumor comple

questions.question:
Question 17: A woman was diagnosed to have metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK 7 (-), CK20 (+), and 
CDX-1 (+) IHC markers. Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin for 
this metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Colorectal carcinoma is the most likely primary tumor for the given metastases. Among the given 
options, cytokeratin 7 is negative only in colon carcinoma. 728 
Sold by @itachibot The most common site of distant metastasis of colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases 
arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. The lung is the next most common 
site for metastasis. Cytokeratin profiles of various primary tumors: CK 7 positiveCK20 positive

questions.question: Question 18: In patients with colorectal carcinoma, which of the following is not a bad prognostic factor?
questions.explanation:
Metachronous lesions are not associated with a bad prognosis in case of liver metastasis from 
colon carcinoma. A metachronous cancer is defined as secondary cancer occurring more than 6 months after the 
index cancer. Synchronous cancer is defined as two or more neoplasms identified simultaneously in the same 
patient, or a second tumor identified within six months after the initial diagnosis. Predictors of poor outcome in colorectal carcinoma with liver metastasis: • Lymph-node-positive primary • Disease-free interval <12 months • More than one tumor • Tumor size >5 cm • Serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level >200 ng/mL

questions.question: Question 19: Patients with which of the following conditions are not suitable for liver transplantation?
questions.explanation:
Cholangiocarcinoma is not an indication for a liver transplant. Orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT) for patients with cholangiocarcinoma had very poor results 
and this treatment strategy has largely been abandoned. 729 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most common indication for liver transplant in children?
questions.explanation:
The most common indication for liver transplant in children is biliary atresia. In biliary atresia, the extrahepatic bile ducts are occluded, causing obstructive jaundice 
(conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia) and progressive liver fibrosis in early infancy. Liver 
transplantation is required if not diagnosed and managed early. (option B) Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) is a progressive liver failure in young children, 
associated with marked hepatic copper overload (in excess of 800 g/g dry weight). Unlike Wilson 
disease, ICC is associated with normal or elevated ceruloplasmin levels, indicating a defect late in 
the copper excretory pathway.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. Which 
of the following is not a parameter in the selection criteria for transplantation?

options.d: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.explanation:
A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is a case of non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure 
and jaundice for more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy is one of the 
parameters in the King's College criteria for liver transplantation. It includes the following parameters: Non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure: • PT >100 s (INR >6.5) or/and • Any three of the following: • Age <10 years or >40 years • Etiology non-A, non-B hepatitis, or idiosyncratic drug reaction • Jaundice more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy i.e., not hyperacute • PT >50 s (INR > 3.5) • Bilirubin > 18 mg/dl (300 mol/L) Paracetamol-induced acute liver failure: • pH <7.30 (irrespective of the grade of encephalopathy) or/and • All three of the following: • Prothrombin time >100 s (INR >6.5) • Serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dl (300 mol/L) • Grade 3 or 4 hepatic encephalopathy

questions.question: Question 22: Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation is indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
730 
Sold by @itachibot Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation (A-OLTX) is indicated in non-cirrhotic metabolic liver 
disease. Auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation is a technique where part of the diseased native 
liver is removed and replaced with a part of the healthy donor liver. This is done so the retained 
native liver can regenerate. In selective cases of acute liver failure, auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation could 
provide a chance for native liver regeneration and immunosuppression-free life. Auxillary orthotopic liver transplant is indicated for the following: • Patients aged <40 years • Reversible fulminant hepatic failure (auxiliary liver transplantation cannot be done in cases of 
irreversible liver failure) • Non-cirrhotic metabolic liver disease • No hemodynamic instability • Hyperacute (not in other cases) Liver failure with Acetaminophen overdose. Auxiliary orthotopic liver tra
